ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned more Spanish grammar and vocab and gained confidence speaking and writing.
I learned a lot about grammar and spanish vocabulary. I also learned about how to apply my learning with specific projects.

The most valuable skill I learned while taking this course was the confidence to speak Spanish. It is hard speaking spanish when you think you are not good at it but being in SPAN 120 where everyone is building friendships based on the language Spanish is really an amazing experience and helped me with key skills such as vocabulary, pronunciation, and proper pronouns.
Learned the past and future tenses as well as the subjunctive mood and several command forms. Learned more about Spanish-speaking cultures around the world.
I learned how to speak Spanish better

I learned a lot about Hispanoblante cultures, societies, and histories. It was really cool to be able to talk to someone from Honduras over Linguameeting and to see cultural differences and similarities.

I learned more about grammar and different tenses in the Spanish language, as well as more about Spanish culture. In comparison to SPAN 110, this class places a larger emphasis on culture and cultural connections, which I enjoyed because it allows us to connect what we were learning about in terms of vocabulary to concepts in the real-world.
spanish

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths include the asynchronous Wednesday class and the professor (Prof. Russell was very understanding and patient)! There are a lot of homework assignments, but all seem to have a broader purpose and most don't seem like busy work. Weaknesses are mostly from the fast pace.

I think the amount of tedious work can be reduced. It felt like it didn't contribute to my learning. We also did not cover grammar concepts enough in class.
I liked the tests formats and supersite.

A couple of strengths were speaking with correct pronunciation and learning how to correctly match gender and number in vocab words and sentences. A weakness that I have that could be improved through more practice in actual spanish speaking is correctly using the correct conjugation of words n sentences.
Expanding available times beyond just the morning.

The repetition of grammar concepts was very helpful in my understanding of them. More writing opportunities would help because using the past and future tenses can be avoided in class so they don't get practiced as much. Perhaps some assignments could be substituted for weekly discussion posts with requirements corresponding to the grammar learned that week/the week prior. For example, a discussion post about how our week went, what we are doing this weekend, or step-by-step instructions (commands) to do something would be beneficial. More monitoring of Supersite assignments would be helpful so that professors can help point out recurring errors. OveralI think more communication with students about where they are at and perhaps optional assignments to help in areas they are struggling, possibly for additional credit, would improve the course. I also think that there should be more explicit opportunities to practice the unit vocabulary throughout the unit instead of having to study over a hundred terms before the exam.
I really enjoyed the projects

One strength is that we did more projects and more cultural activities in class however, one weakness is that this class is very fast paced, and sometimes we will have alot of homework and assignments at the same time.
moves too fast, very hard to truly learn vocab or grammar

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only if you have to take it--it's fun to learn a new language and the course is very manageable, but I wouldn't recommend taking it if it doesn't fulfill a requirement.

I would. I think that the workload is manageable as long as you plan ahead, but to be prepared for the tediousness of the work. I think the professor is great and understanding, but it oftentimes feels like I got points deduced from my work for no reason.
No.
I would recommend this course. It is a great continued introduction tothe Spanish language and Spanish-speaking cultures.
Yes, I think the class was well taught and engaging
If you to learn Spanish, to truly learn it, this is a great course for you!
I would recommend this course to another student if they did well in SPAN 110 or have a very good foundation in the basics of the Spanish language.
if you really want to learn spanish, sure, but its hard
